title: Scientific Evidence for BMAC Therapy
tagline: Bone marrow concentrate for joint preservation and osteonecrosis
description: Randomized and long-term cohort studies evaluating bone marrow aspirate concentrate for knee osteoarthritis and osteonecrosis.
longDescription: Prospective randomized studies compare BMAC injections to contralateral arthroplasty and exercise therapy, demonstrating improved pain and function with delayed need for replacement surgery. Fifteen to thirty-year follow-ups in osteonecrosis cohorts show sustained benefit and lower revision rates versus surgical controls.

seo.metaTitle: Scientific Evidence | Bone Marrow Aspirate Concentrate (BMAC)
seo.metaDescription: Review randomized and long-term studies on bone marrow concentrate injections for knee osteoarthritis and osteonecrosis.

hero.headline: Evidence for Bone Marrow Concentrate
hero.subheadline: Studies up to 15–30 years show functional gains and delayed arthroplasty.

overview.title: What the Literature Shows
overview.content: Subchondral and intra-articular BMAC injections have been compared with arthroplasty, exercise therapy, and placebo controls. Trials report meaningful WOMAC and VAS improvements, with several studies noting reduced progression to joint replacement at long-term follow-up.
highlights: Randomized comparisons to arthroplasty and exercise therapy
Long-term cohorts (15–30 years) in osteonecrosis and OA
Endpoints: pain scores, function, arthroplasty-free survival

howItWorks.title: Why Marrow-Derived Cells Matter
howItWorks.subtitle: Concentrated MSCs, growth factors, and cytokines support cartilage and bone.
howItWorks.content: BMAC delivers a high concentration of mesenchymal stem cells and signalling molecules harvested from the iliac crest. Injected into the joint or subchondral bone, they modulate inflammation, support cartilage repair, and may reinforce subchondral architecture to delay structural progression.

benefits.title: High cell potency
benefits.description: Marrow concentrate provides MSCs plus growth factors in a single procedure.

benefits.title: Subchondral support
benefits.description: Studies show targeted subchondral delivery can stabilise bone and cartilage.

benefits.title: Durable outcomes
benefits.description: Long-term cohorts report extended arthroplasty-free survival.

steps.title: Baseline Assessment
steps.description: Radiographic grading and pain/function scores (WOMAC, VAS) documented.

steps.title: Guided Injection
steps.description: Ultrasound or fluoroscopy-guided BMAC delivered intra-articularly or into subchondral bone.

steps.title: Follow-up 6–24+ Months
steps.description: Pain and function reassessed; some studies follow patients to 15–30 years for arthroplasty-free survival.

items.title: Pain & function gains
items.description: Prospective studies show improved WOMAC and VAS compared with controls.

items.title: Delays surgery
items.description: Randomized comparisons suggest lower conversion to arthroplasty in treated knees.

items.title: Favourable safety profile
items.description: Adverse events are uncommon and typically limited to transient soreness.

faq.question: How long do benefits last in studies?
faq.answer: Many cohorts report improvements through 12–24 months; long-term osteonecrosis data track patients for 15–30 years with reduced arthroplasty rates.

faq.question: Where is BMAC injected in trials?
faq.answer: Protocols vary, but subchondral and intra-articular approaches are both reported, often combined with imaging guidance.

faq.question: What are the main risks?
faq.answer: Published studies note low complication rates, primarily temporary post-procedure discomfort at the harvest or injection site.
